recItems.blurb: This is a unique hybrid of a book, made from various genres: memoir, travelogue, cultural study, academic research. Baz does a great job to educate and inform while taking readers on a rich global journey, of human stories—all in an effort to put a human face on a worldwide justice struggle. It was such an honor to meet Baz this November, 2017 at the [Female Imprisonment Worldwide](http://www.prisonstudies.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/invitation_and_programme_wfil_final.pdf) event in London, where I was a speaker.
recItems.headline: *Incarceration Nations: A Journey to Justice in Prisons Around the World*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: I had the honor of meeting Bryan Stevenson, both being speakers at the [Acumen  Global gathering](https://acumen.org/blog/acumen-fellows-global-gathering-set-to-convene-300-social-entrepreneurs/) in Naivasha, Kenya in March 2017. Bryan Stevenson whom Desmond Tutu calls 'America's Mandela', has devoted his life to exposing racial bias in the US penal system. In this memoir, true story about the redeeming potential of mercy, Bryan personalises the struggle against injustice.
recItems.headline: *Just Mercy: A Story of Justice and Redemption*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb:
To mark the BBC World Service 100 Women season, Caroline Bayley speaks to six former women prisoners, across three continents. They were convicted under different circumstances and of different crimes - but they are united in their passion for business enterprise and self-employment which has allowed them to turn their lives around on the outside. Teresa Njoroge and one of the women beneficiaries of [Clean Start](http://cleanstart.co.ke/), are among those featured.

You can listen to the women featured in this article [here](http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p04k007p).
recItems.headline: "100 Women: From prison to profit"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

recItems.blurb: Clean Start participated at the Understanding and Reducing the Use of Imprisonment Worldwide event, held by the Institute for Criminal Policy Research, Birkbeck University of London.
recItems.headline: "PRISON: Evidence of its use and overuse from around the world"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

Jessica Jacobson, Catherine Heard, Helen Fair
Institute for Criminal Policy Research and Fair Trials, 2017

nodes.description: Criminal and social justice reform advocate
nodes.whoTheyAre: At Clean Start Kenya, Teresa Njoroge builds bridges connecting the formerly imprisoned to the outside world and vice versa.
nodes.whyListen:
Teresa Njoroge is the cofounder and CEO of Clean Start Kenya. She was pursuing her childhood dream, a career in banking, when she was falsely accused of a fraudulent transaction. Sentenced to imprisonment in the High Security Langata Women’s Maximum Prison, Njoroge was forced to bring her three-month-old baby with her.

What began as a loss of career and social standing led to her purpose in life, advocating for Kenyan women, youth and men trapped in a cycle of poverty, survival, petty crimes and life behind bars and equipping them with entrepreneurial skills, jobs and formal education. Later cleared of any wrongdoing, Njoroge is now a beacon of hope and second chances to thousands, with her mission to build up the bottom-of-the-pyramid economy and an inclusive Africa. As she writes: "I am an optimistic, self-driven social entrepreneur with over a decade of progressive experience in economic and social justice work, in my journey from 'I can do it' to 'I did it'!"

videoData.description: In 2011, Teresa Njoroge was convicted of a financial crime she didn't commit -- the result of a long string of false accusations, increasing bribe attempts and the corrupt justice system in her home in Kenya. Once incarcerated, she discovered that most of the women and girls locked up with her were also victims of the same broken system, caught in a revolving door of life in and out of prison due to poor education and lack of economic opportunity. Now free and cleared by the courts of appeal, Njoroge shares how she's giving women in prison the skills, tools and support they need to break the cycle of poverty and crime and build a better life.

cues.text: I knew it was for real.
How could they send me here?
How could they make such a huge mistake

without any repercussions
whatsoever to their actions?
I see large groups of women
surrounded by huge walls and gates,
and I get hit by an awful stench,

from working in the respected
financial banking sector,
having worked so hard in school,
at Langata Women Maximum Security Prison

I was informed that I had handled
a fraudulent transaction unknowingly
at the bank where I worked.
I was shocked, scared and terrified.

I would lose a career
that I loved passionately.
But that was not the worst.

It got even worse
than I could have ever imagined.

The absurdity of it all
was the arresting officer
asking me to pay him 10,000 US dollars
Two and a half years on,
It was all over the media,
This time around, said to me,
the judgement will be in your favor,"

irrespective of the fact
that there was no evidence whatsoever
on the charges that I was up against.
The cold, hard face of the judge
for a crime that I hadn't committed.
whom I had just named Oma,

which in my dialect
means "truth and justice,"
as that was what I had longed so much for

I dressed her in her
favorite purple dress,
and here she was, about to accompany me

The guards did not seem
sensitive to the trauma
that this experience was causing me.

It involved me being
searched for contrabands,
forced to squat on the ground,
a posture that I soon came to learn

I was no longer referred to
as Teresa Njoroge.
The number 415/11 was my new identity,

and I soon learned that was
the case with the other women
who we were sharing this space with.
And adjust I did to life on the inside:
Prison is certainly no fairytale world.
What I didn't see come my way
whom we served time and shared space with,
the corruption that requires a fall guy,
so that the person who is responsible

a broken system that routinely
vilifies the vulnerable,
people who cannot afford to pay bail
As I listened to story after story
during that one year in prison,

was not what had brought
these women to prison,
It had started with the education system,

whose supply and quality
is not equal for all;

that pushes these women
to petty survival crimes;
who were mostly from poor backgrounds,
the bottom of that chasm is a prison,

By the time I completed
my one-year sentence
to be part of the transformation
who were caught up in a revolving door
of a life in and out of prison
Clean Start is a social enterprise
that seeks to give these women and girls
What we do is we build bridges for them.
We go into the prisons, train them,
give them skills, tools and support

to enable them to be able
to change their mindsets,
We also build bridges into the prisons
that will partner with Clean Start
to enable us to provide employment,
of the injustices that are so common
Every time I go back to prison,
I feel a little at home,
but it is the daunting work
that keeps me awake at night,

which is deemed as the incarceration
capital of the world,
whom I have met within the prisons,

some of whom are now
embracing their second chances,

and others who are still
on that bridge of life's journey.
and two years post my release,
I got cleared by the courts of appeal
I got blessed with my son,
Because I had finally gotten the freedom
that thousands of us have come together

to reform and transform
the criminal justice system,
encouraged that we are doing our jobs
as we are meant to do them.
And let us keep doing them

footnotes.annotation:
> My first night at Langata Women Maximum Security Prison was the toughest.

Langata Women's Prison (LWP) is the only all women's prison in Nairobi.  It is a big compound, but there are over 750 prisoners, 50 children accompanying their incarcerated mothers and there are over 400 staff that reside in the prison compound due to security. LWP is comprised of a Remand Centre for short sentences and those awaiting trial or sentencing, a Medium Security Section for slightly longer sentences, and then the Maximum Security for the convicted and what we would consider federal offenses and long-term sentences.  There is also an onsite Nursery School where the prison staff children attend, the children of the prisoners and also some outside children are permitted to attend.  Children are allowed to stay with their mothers until they are 4 years old.  If the mother is still in prison once the child turns 4 then the child is sent to a children's home until the mother is discharged. There are even children born there!  What a setting for a child. 

[Behind Bars: A Look at Life in One of Kenya's Most Notorious Prisons](http://www.eadestination.com/investigative-journalism/43-behind-bars-a-look-at-life-in-one-of-kenya-s-most-notorious-prisons), Destination Magazine

> The absurdity of it all was the arresting officer asking me to pay him 10,000 US dollars and the case would disappear. I refused.

Interference with the criminal justice system is common practice in Kenya.  A popular saying, "Why hire a lawyer when you can buy a judge?" sums up many Kenyan's views of Judicial integrity.

[*Corruption in Africa: The Kenyan Experience: a Handbook for Civic Education*](https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1oiRyqnJpAwC&pg=PA25&lpg=PA25&dq=paying+of+bribes+and+the+corruption+in+the+kenya+courts+and+criminal+justice+system&source=bl&ots=_vS_h-6Bn0&sig=Sxa7qrD6sQjY1h0IsMBj5uueWOg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjIlpu4z7bXAhViBsAKHVVfBu8Q6AEIVzAJ#v=onepage&q=paying%20of%20bribes%20and%20the%20corruption%20in%20the%20kenya%20courts%20and%20criminal%20justice%20system&f=false), Peter Anassi, 2004

> A broken system that routinely vilifies the vulnerable, the poorest amongst us, people who cannot afford to pay bail or bribes.

[Transforming the Courts: Judicial Sector Reforms in Kenya, 2011-2015](https://successfulsocieties.princeton.edu/sites/successfulsocieties/files/MG_OGP_Kenya.pdf), Princeton University

> Lack of economic opportunities that pushes these women to petty survival crimes.

Kenya’s rate of unemployment stands at three times that of the neighboring Uganda and Tanzania, also among the highest in the world - according to a World Bank report.

[Kenya has the largest number of jobless youth in East Africa](http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Kenya-tops-East-Africa-s-list-of-youth-joblessness/539546-3108514-6cd5xgz/index.html), Business Daily

[Kenya: Joblessness Major Cause of Crime in Kenya's Slums](http://allafrica.com/stories/201410160194.html), All Africa

> We go into the prisons, train them, give them skills, tools and support to enable them to be able to change their mindsets, their behaviors and their attitudes.

At [Clean Start](http://cleanstart.co.ke/our-work/), we have adapted the award-winning [Spear Course](http://www.resurgo.org.uk/spear/) from Resurgo Trust UK, which has recently been awarded the Princess Royal Training Award for using executive coaching techniques.
